Capilano CW supplies about 1/3 of the drinking water to the Metro Vancouver area (about 500,000 serviced properties total for all three watersheds used).  The Capilano Reservoir, a surface water source, is situated behind the Cleveland Dam and is approximately 5.4 kilometres in length by 0.80 kilometres wide.  Palisade Reservoir is an alpine lake located upstream of the Capilano Reservoir and is used to augment flow to the Capilano Reservoir during the dry season.  Up until March 2015, chlorine was the sole primary disinfection added to the water at the intake location near the Cleveland Dam.  Now the water is pumped, via tunnel, to the Seymour-Capilano Filtration Plant in the Seymour watershed where it is treated and disinfected.  Treated water is returned, via tunnel, to the Capilano Reservoir service area and then enters the transmission system to supply the Capilano service area.

Seymour CW supplies about 1/3 of the drinking water to the Metro Vancouver area (about 500,000 serviced properties total for all three watersheds used).  The Seymour Reservoir, a surface water source situated behind the Seymour Falls Dam, is approximately 6.5 kilometres in length and between 0.20 and 0.75 kilometres wide.  Both Loch Lomond alpine reservoir, found upstream of the Seymour Reservoir and Burwell alpine reservoir, found above the existing reservoir, are used to augment flow to the Seymour Reservoir during the dry season.  Since 2009, water is sent to the Seymour-Capilano Filtration Plant in the Seymour watershed where it is treated and disinfected.  Treated water then enters the distribution system to supply the Seymour service area.
